newsitem.title: USA: Crude oil soars within a breath of post Gulf War high.
newsitem.headline: Crude oil soars within a breath of post Gulf War high.

text.p: Crude oil prices on Monday rose within a breath of their post-Gulf War highs during a day of unexpectedly wild trade on the New York Mercantile Exchange, traders said.
News of production problems over the weekend at a BP America refinery in Toledo, Ohio, heated the market up late Monday morning, forcing sceptics to reconsider their positions.
"That was the straw that broke the camel's back," said Nauman Barakat, a trader with Prudential Securities in New York, referring to the BP story. "This is very much a bullish market," Barakat said.

Crude futures for November delivery on the NYMEX settled 96 cents higher at $25.62 a barrel after hitting a contract high of $25.68 -- a touch shy of the $25.70 post Gulf War high set this past spring -- earlier in the day.

Traders said the writing on the wall was in London, where crude futures for November delivery on the International Petroleum Exchange Monday set a post-Gulf War high at $24.80 a barrel or 88 cents higher than Friday's settlement.
Much of the market's strength on both sides of the Atlantic continued to be linked to tight supplies of distillates such as diesel or heating oil, traders said.
Heating oil led the upward NYMEX charge on Monday, with the contract for November delivery gaining 2.64 cents and settling at 74.07 cents a gallon.
Traders looked forward to the American Petroleum Institute's (API) weekly inventory report, due late Tuesday, for a fresh view of just how tight heating oil stocks are.
"If we don't get a build in heating oil stocks of two to three million barrels, this market could go to 80 cents a gallon," said Tom Bentz, analyst with ING Derivatives Clearing in New York.
Heating oil stocks on the East Coast, the largest heating oil market in the world, are now at 24.5 million barrels, or 40 percent below year-ago levels.
Gasoline for November delivery settled 2.18 cents higher at 67.70 cents a gallon -- just a touch shy of a contract high of 67.80 cents set during the session.
Other markets, however, were in a less bullish mood and the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities fell by 0.21 points to 245.49.
Soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade fell to a 10-month low as the prospects for this year's U.S. crop continued to improved amid almost ideal harvest weather.

The market was already on the defensive following Friday's government U.S. production estimate of 2.35 billion bushels, which would be the second largest soybean crop ever. Soybeans fell the 30-cent daily trading limit on Friday.
"There was spillover from the crop report and the good harvest weather weighed on it," said Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds.
The fall sparked talk that China may pull out of recent purchases to take advantage of cheaper price levels.

Last week the USDA reported China purchased 50,000 tonnes of U.S. soymeal and 55,000 tonnes of U.S. soybeans in the week ended October 3 and traders expected more sales to be reported when data for the following week is issued on Thursday.
"There are big fears China may cancel their bean or meal purchases," one CBOT soybean trader said.
November soybeans closed 11-3/4 cents a bushel lower at $6.88-1/2 after earlier dipping to a low of $6.82.

Corn futures also dipped to a 10-month low early on follow-through selling after a bearish U.S. government report Friday which put U.S. production at 9.01 billion bushels, which would represent the third largest crop ever.
The market then recoverd, boosted partly by sentiment the fall had been overdone with commercials featured buyers.
December corn closed 2-3/4 cents higher at $2.86-1/2 after falling early to a low of $2.82-1/4.
